name: Bangkok
intro_vibe: The City of Angels: Where golden temples meet neon-lit chaos and street food reigns supreme.

general_info.description: Bangkok is the capital and most populous city of Thailand. A vibrant metropolis that never sleeps, Bangkok offers a sensory overload of ornate temples, bustling markets, world-class street food, and a nightlife that ranges from rooftop bars to raucous nightclubs. The city seamlessly blends ancient tradition with modern development, creating a uniquely chaotic yet captivating experience.

weather_breakdown.name: September
weather_breakdown.clothing: Mix of sun and rain gear

etiquette_tips: Respect the Monarchy: Never disrespect the King or Royal Family. It is illegal and deeply offensive.
Don't Touch Heads: The head is sacred. Never touch anyone's head, including children.
Remove Shoes: Take off shoes before entering temples, homes, and some shops.
Dress Modestly: Cover shoulders and knees at temples. No tank tops.
Wai Greeting: Press palms together and bow slightly. Don't wai service workers first.
Spice is Serious: 'Medium' spice is very hot. Order 'Mai Phet' (no spice) or 'Phet Nit Noi' (little spice) to be safe.
Street Food Seating: Plastic stools and shared tables are normal. Don't wait to be seated.
Cash is King: Street vendors and taxis rarely take cards. Keep small bills (20s, 50s, 100s) handy.
Cool Down: 7-Eleven and malls are essential cooling centers during the midday heat.

essential_phrases.local: เท่าไหร่ (Tao rai)

neighborhoods.name: Khao San Road
neighborhoods.description: The legendary backpacker street. Cheap hostels, street food, bucket cocktails, and travelers from every corner of the globe. Chaotic and touristy but essential Bangkok.

neighborhoods.name: Sukhumvit
neighborhoods.description: Bangkok's main expat and tourist district. High-end malls, rooftop bars, international restaurants, and red-light areas. Ultra-modern and connected by BTS Skytrain.

neighborhoods.name: Rattanakosin (Old City)
neighborhoods.description: The heart of royal Bangkok. Grand Palace, Wat Pho, and Wat Arun are all here. Crowded with tourists but essential for temple hopping and history.

neighborhoods.name: Chinatown (Yaowarat)
neighborhoods.description: Neon-lit chaos of gold shops, street food stalls, and traditional Chinese medicine stores. The best street food in Bangkok is found here, especially at night.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: The BTS Skytrain and MRT are your best friends. Taxis are cheap but traffic is brutal.
details: BTS Skytrain: Elevated train covering central areas. Fast, cold AC, and skips traffic.
MRT Metro: Underground lines connecting key areas. Separate ticketing from BTS.
River Boats: The Orange Flag boat is the best way to see temples without traffic.
Grab: Use the app for cars/bikes. Safer than negotiating with street taxis.
Taxis: Insist on 'Meter Na Krap/Ka'. If they refuse, walk away.

logistics.title: Red-Light Districts
logistics.summary: Adult entertainment zones exist. They are localized and optional.
details: Key Areas: Patpong (Silom), Nana Plaza (Sukhumvit), Soi Cowboy (Asok).
The Reality: While technically illegal, these zones are regulated and tolerated. They are not representative of daily Thai life.
Advice: Participation is optional. Aggressive touting and scams ('Ping Pong Shows') are common. Avoid venues with pushy staff outside.
Photography: Strictly forbidden in these areas.

logistics.title: Scams to Avoid
logistics.summary: Bangkok has friendly people, but tourist scams are common. Stay alert.
details: Tuk-Tuk Gem Scam: Driver offers cheap tour and takes you to a gem shop. They get commission, you get overpriced stones.
Temple Closed Scam: Stranger says the Grand Palace is closed today. It isn't. Ignore them.
Taxi Meter Scam: Taxi refuses to use the meter. Insist on the meter or get out.
Jet Ski Scam: Avoid renting jet skis; operators often claim false damage charges.

logistics.title: Safety Basics
logistics.summary: Bangkok is generally safe, but use common sense in crowded areas.
details: Pickpockets: Active in crowded areas like Chatuchak Market and Khao San Road.
Traffic: Vehicles do not stop for pedestrians. Cross with extreme caution.
Mosquitoes: Dengue fever is a risk. Use repellent, especially at dusk.
Emergency Number: 191 for police, 1669 for ambulance.

logistics.title: Apps to Download
logistics.summary: These apps will make Bangkok navigation seamless.
details: Grab: Essential for taxis and food delivery.
Google Maps: Works well for transit and walking.
Wongnai: The 'Thai Yelp' for food reviews.
Klook: Good for discount tickets to attractions.

must_eat.description: Thailand's most famous dish: stir-fried rice noodles with shrimp or chicken, eggs, peanuts, bean sprouts, and tamarind sauce. Street cart versions are often better than restaurant ones.
The real national dish. Minced pork or chicken stir-fried with holy basil, garlic, and chili, served over rice with a crispy fried egg (Kai Dao). Spicy and savory.
Iconic hot and sour soup with shrimp, lemongrass, galangal, kaffir lime leaves, and chili. Intensely aromatic and flavorful.

must_eat.name_local: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเรือ
must_eat.description: Rich, dark noodle soup thickened with pig blood (nam tok). Traditionally served in tiny bowls, so locals order stacks of them at once.

must_eat.name_local: ข้าวมันไก่
must_eat.description: Poached chicken served on oily ginger-garlic rice with a spicy dipping sauce and cucumber. A simple, comforting lunch staple everywhere.
Spicy, sour, sweet, and crunchy salad made from shredded green papaya, tomatoes, peanuts, and chili. Order 'mai phet' (not spicy) if you can't handle heat.

must_eat.name_local: ข้าวเหนียวมะม่วง
must_eat.description: Sweet sticky rice cooked in coconut milk, served with ripe mango slices. The perfect end to a spicy meal.
Sweet and savory marinated pork grilled over charcoal. A favorite breakfast or late-night snack, usually eaten with a bag of sticky rice.

must_eat.name_local: แกงมัสมั่น
must_eat.description: Rich, mild curry with Persian influences. Made with beef or chicken, potatoes, peanuts, and coconut milk. Less spicy, more sweet.

must_eat.name_local: อาหารอีสาน
must_eat.description: Cuisine from Northeast Thailand. Think grilled chicken (Gai Yang), spicy minced meat salad (Larb), and sticky rice. Bold, funky, and spicy.
Crispy egg batter fried with plump oysters or mussels, served with bean sprouts and chili sauce. A greasy, delicious Chinatown classic.
Look for Kanom Krok (coconut pancakes) or Bualoy (rice balls in coconut milk). Usually sweet, warm, and very cheap.

items.name_local: พระบรมมหาราชวัง
items.description: The most iconic landmark. Former royal residence with stunning architecture and the Emerald Buddha.
Temple of Dawn. Stunning riverside temple with a towering colorful spire. Climb the steep steps for a view.
Home to the massive Reclining Buddha and the birthplace of Thai massage. Peaceful and beautiful.

items.name_local: เรือด่วนเจ้าพระยา
items.description: The local way to travel. Take the Orange Flag boat for a cheap, scenic cruise past the temples. Authentic and breezy.
After dark, Chinatown turns into the world's greatest street food buffet. Neon lights, crowds, and incredible seafood.
Affordable and intense. Visit a reputable shop or the massage school at Wat Pho. Part of daily health maintenance here.

items.name_local: สวนลุมพินี
items.description: Bangkok's 'Central Park'. Go at 7 AM to see locals doing Tai Chi, or sunset for aerobics. Watch out for monitor lizards.
Thailand's national sport. Watch a real fight at Rajadamnern Stadium for the noise, gambling, and atmosphere.

items.name_local: ตลาดนัดจตุจักร
items.description: 15,000 stalls selling everything from vintage clothes to pets. Hot, crowded, and essential. Weekend only.

items.name_local: ตลาดนัดกลางคืน
items.description: Evening markets with food, bars, and live music. Less touristy than Chatuchak. Great for dinner and hanging out.

items.name_local: ปากคลองตลาด
items.description: Massive 24-hour flower market. Best visited late at night or very early morning. A riot of colors and smells.

items.name_local: บาร์บนดาดฟ้า
items.description: Sunset drinks with a view. Octave, Tichuca, or Vertigo are popular choices. Dress code usually applies (no flip-flops).

affiliate_products.title: Portable Neck Fan
affiliate_products.reason: Bangkok heat is brutal. A hands-free neck fan keeps you cool while sightseeing.

affiliate_products.title: Mosquito Repellent
affiliate_products.reason: Dengue is a risk. DEET-based repellent is essential for outdoor evenings.

affiliate_products.title: Travel Money Belt
affiliate_products.reason: Pickpockets are active in markets. Keep your cash secure.
